description: A short-sword made for use in the United State artillery during the mid 19th century. Although it looks like a sword, it was principally used as a machete that was more fit for cutting brush than people, and as such is a fairly poor combat weapon. As a side arm, it was used by soldiers in artillery regiments in both sides of the civil war.

Perhaps as much a symbol of the Japanese Empire's military strategy as their aircraft carriers or banzai charges, the Type 30 bayonet was their most widely produced bayonet with over 8 million produced. It saw use from the frozen wastes of Manhcuria in the Russo-Japanese war to the tropical hell of the pacific. Designed in part to give Japanese infantrymen the reach to attack cavalrymen, the blade is among the longest ever made for any mass-produced bayonet at over fifteen inches in length.
A very odd hybrid of a KA-BAR, the famed combat knife of the USMC with a Japanese Katana. Who made this, and for what purpose, is entirely unknown.

An obscure weapon that's an eclectic mix of revolver, brass knucle and push knife. Allegedely used by a gang of French criminals, Les Apaches. This version has be rechambered for the more common .38 cartridge.

A shooting knife made by China on the eve of the new millenium, the QSB-91 was intended for use with Chinese Special forces and police forces. It has a fixed blade with four fixed barrels that can be fired in sequence. Although the QSB-91 is typically chambered for the 7.65mm round, this version has been rechambered for .32 ACP

Designed by the Global Research and Development (G.R.A.D.) firm in the 1990s, this knife is a hybrid mixture of .22lr revolver and combat knife. The hilt can unfold to reveal a small .22lr revolving cylinder, complete with its own barrel that's flush with the edge of the knife blade.
